An editorial theme for tumblr

In 2010 I was looking for a sober, type-led tumblr theme to start jotting down design concerns that occupied my thoughts. I’m not a good writer and my ideas are few and far between, but as @RellyAB once said, To become a good writer, you need to do a lot of shitty writing first.[1]

By using the tumblr platform, the predicted paucity of written updates could at least be mitigated with other types of media to keep it from becoming another graveyard. It also had the added benefit of being separate from my portfolio in case it was complete garbage.

There were (and are) a wealth of themes to choose from, but I couldn’t find precisely what I was looking for. Either the type choices weren’t right, or it had artefacts or detailing I found extraneous, or it was just too gimmicky. (On reflection, this whole foray might have just have been a subconscious avoidance strategy to keep me from doing what I feared. Still, it was a good exercise… )

Georgia ++

The most important component to get right was the typeface. At this point I was already a huge fan of Georgia, having used it for my last portfolio. Its ubiquity is a testament to the decisions Matthew Carter made and how well it performs, but it also prevents us from fully seeing its beauty. (If you look into the decisions you can get an idea why it performs so well.) Around this time, Webtype had released Georgia Pro[2], an updated version of the Matthew Carter classic with new weights and extra hinting. Side-by-side, the new letters looked even better.

RWD FTW

Sometime in mid-2012 the words 'responsive and 'design' accounted for about 65% of the words in my twitterfeed, but it was only when Front-Ender/UX Designer/pal @steveavery sent a working demo[3] around the office that the penny dropped for me.

Responsive design was such a huge revelation that might have actually rewired my brain, much in the same way CSS did a decade earlier. The mental model I had been using up until this point had been.

Revisiting the source for this 4 years later makes me appreciated (even more) how useful all the build tools we now have are. Back then, I was writing vanilla CSS, manually typing out vendor-prefixes, meticulously indenting and then minifying with some online service. Ridiculous. But at least it kept me from writing.

  2. The demo in question was (I think) from Leigh Howells at Headscape which I can't seme to track down now. I'll email and update.
  3. Georgia Pro & Verdana Pro: More Widths. More Weights. More Possibilities.
